definitions_glossary.proper_divisor: A divisor of n that is less than n (excludes n itself)
definitions_glossary.aliquot_sum: The sum of proper divisors of a number, denoted s(n) = σ(n) - n
definitions_glossary.divisor_function: σ(n) is the sum of all positive divisors of n
definitions_glossary.mersenne_prime: A prime of the form 2^p - 1 where p is prime
definitions_glossary.abundant_number: A number where σ(n) - n > n (sum of proper divisors exceeds the number)
definitions_glossary.deficient_number: A number where σ(n) - n < n (sum of proper divisors is less than the number)

properties: All known perfect numbers are even
Even perfect numbers end in 6 or 28 (in base 10)
Every even perfect number is triangular (sum of consecutive integers)
The digital root of all perfect numbers (except 6) is 1
Perfect numbers are the solutions to σ(n) = 2n
There are only 51 known perfect numbers (as of 2024)

open_problems.partial_results: If one exists, it must be > 10^1500 and have at least 101 prime factors

open_problems.problem: Are there infinitely many perfect numbers?
open_problems.connection: Equivalent to asking if there are infinitely many Mersenne primes

euclid_euler_theorem.statement: n is an even perfect number ⟺ n = 2^(p-1) × (2^p - 1) where 2^p - 1 is a Mersenne prime
euclid_euler_theorem.historical_note: Euclid proved (→) around 300 BCE; Euler proved (←) in 1747

definition.@value: A positive integer equal to the sum of its proper positive divisors

pedagogical.historical_context: Perfect numbers fascinated ancient Greek mathematicians who associated them with perfection and divine harmony. Euclid proved the fundamental theorem about even perfect numbers around 300 BCE, but Euler didn't complete the characterization until 1747—a 2000-year gap!
